bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, November 2, 1949

div1.p: Siler regrets that Hench is unable to attend the annual meeting of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. He discusses his visit with Bliss and his efforts to preserve Building No. 1. Siler informs Hench about his plans to have a plaque placed on the wall of a building where Reed had died.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, November 2, 1949
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
November 2, 1949
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
This will acknowledge receipt of your note of October 20th advising
me that it will be impossible for you to attend the annual meeting of the
Walter Reed Memorial Association this year. We very much regret that you cannot
come.

I am enclosing herewith copy of the letter being sent out to all the
members of the Board advising them of the date and place of the annual meeting
and calling attention to the copy of your letter to me under date of October 20th.

I went down to see General Bliss at the Office of the Surgeon General a
few days ago relative to the plaque to be placed on the building at Ft. Leslie
McNair and also with respect to your information concerning Building #1 in Cuba.
We will of course take these matters up at the annual meeting, but General Bliss
told me he would be very glad to do anything possible to get some action with
respect to Building #1.

I anticipate going to Ft. McNair in the next few days with General
Reed and we will see the Commanding Officer with regard to placing the plaque
on the building. I talked with General Kean last week and we thought it might
be well to have the plaque made of metal with the lettering to be of suitable size
and visibility to be able to be read from the sidewalk. Tentatively, we thought
the following inscription might be satisfactory: "Walter Reed died in this building,
then a hospital, November 23, 1902. We would like very much to have your suggestions
concerning the wording and any changes in it you consider desirable.

We shall look forward with great pleasure to seeing you when you do come
to Washington later in the year.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. F. Siler
Col., U.S.A., Retired Enclosure.
